questions.text: Which of the following drugs used as nail lacquer belongs to morpholines? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amorolfine

 

  • Amorolfine is a morpholine that is available as a 5% nail lacquer. Amorolfine inhibits two separate stages in the synthesis of ergosterol and is fungicidal.
  • It is used in the treatment of onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxiconazole:

  • This is an azole antifungal drug.
  • Azoles work by inhibiting the enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which is crucial in converting lanosterol to ergosterol.

 

Option C. Ciclopirox olamine:

  • Ciclopirox is a hydroxypyridone antifungal agent, not a morpholine.

 

 

  • It acts by chelating polyvalent cations, resulting in the inhibition of the metal-dependent enzymes responsible for the degradation of peroxides within fungal cells.

 

Option D. Tioconazole:

 

Tioconazole is another azole antifungal agent and, like oxiconazole, works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amorolfine is the only morpholine derivative, used as a nail lacquer for the treatment of fungal infections.

 

Reference - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 18 Page no 18.12

Online resources: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20737634/

https://ijdvl.com/onychomycosis-diagnosis-and-management/

questions.text: Identify A and B in the image given: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-Anopheles, B-Culex

 

The image shows mosquito larvae in water. Anopheles larvae (A) rest parallel to the water surface because they have no siphon tube and can take oxygen directly through the water surface and skin. In contrast, Culex larvae (B) have a siphon tube (like a nose) so they attach to water surface at an angle using this siphon tube. The characteristic positioning of these larvae helps in their identification - Anopheles parallel to surface, while Culex at an angle.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. A-Culex, B-Aedes: Incorrect because Culex larvae rest at an angle to water surface, not parallel like shown in A.

 

Option C. A-Culex, B-Anopheles: Incorrect because the positioning is reversed. Anopheles rests parallel (A), not B.

 

Option D. A-Aedes, B-Culex: Incorrect because Aedes larvae, like Culex, have a siphon tube and rest at an angle, not parallel like shown in A.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An elderly patient complains of multiple clots in his urine. Which catheter should be used in this patient which can facilitate irrigation and clot removal from the urinary bladder? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 22 French Foley's 3 lumen catheter

 

Explanation: 


A triple lumen catheter is ideal for managing clots in bladder as it has:

 

  • First channel for urine drainage
  • Second channel for balloon inflation
  • Third channel specifically for continuous irrigation
  • 22 French size is appropriate for adequate drainage of clots
  • Commonly used after procedures like TURP where post-operative clots are expected
  • Allows simultaneous irrigation and drainage

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 22 French Foley's 4 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Does not exist in clinical practice
  • No requirement for fourth lumen

 

Option C. 22 French Foley's 2 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Has only drainage and balloon inflation channels
  • No separate channel for irrigation
  • Cannot perform continuous irrigation effectively

 

Option D. 22 French Foley's 1 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Cannot be self-retaining as no balloon inflation channel
  • No irrigation capability
  • Inadequate for managing clots
  • Not practical for this clinical scenario

 

Educational Objective: 


A three-way Foley's catheter (22Fr) is the appropriate choice for managing bladder clots as it allows simultaneous drainage and irrigation through separate channels.

questions.text: A child was brought with pedal edema and cheilosis. Further investigations revealed cardiomegaly. What is the vitamin deficiency associated with this clinical presentation?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

The given clinical presentation with pedal edema and cardiomegaly is suggestive of wet beriberi, which is a consequence of thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency, also known as beriberi, is a more likely candidate. Thiamine deficiency can manifest as cardiac beriberi, leading to an enlarged heart (cardiomegaly), which aligns with the clinical findings. Thiamine deficiency can also cause peripheral edema, such as pedal edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Riboflavin deficiency can lead to cheilosis, which is consistent with one of the symptoms observed. However, it is not typically associated with pedal edema or cardiomegaly.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency is not commonly associated with pedal edema, cheilosis, or cardiomegaly.

 

Option D. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which includes symptoms like dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It is not typically associated with cardiomegaly or pedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 deficiency disorders

questions.text: What is the lowest detection limit for third-generation TSH assays? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.004 mIU/L

 

The third-generation TSH immunochemiluminometric assays (ICMAs) have extremely high sensitivity, capable of detecting very low TSH levels. Extremely sensitive assays can detect TSH levels ≤0.004 mIU/L, though for practical clinical purposes, assays sensitive to ≤0.1 mIU/L are generally sufficient. This high sensitivity is what allows these modern assays to discriminate between the lower limit of the normal range and the suppressed values seen in thyrotoxicosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.04 mIU/L: This value is incorrect as it is 10 times higher than the actual detection limit of third-generation TSH assays, which can detect levels down to 0.004 mIU/L.

 

Option B. 0.1 mIU/L: This represents the practical sensitivity threshold that is considered sufficient for most clinical purposes, but is not the actual detection limit of third-generation assays.

 

Option D. 0.0044 mIU/L: This value is incorrect. The detection limit for extremely sensitive third-generation TSH assays is 0.004 mIU/L.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third-generation TSH immunochemiluminometric assays can detect TSH levels as low as 0.004 mIU/L, which is essential for discriminating between the lower limit of the normal reference range and the suppressed values found in thyrotoxicosis, though for most clinical applications, assays with sensitivity to 0.1 mIU/L are adequate.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old patient who has presented with easily rupturing flaccid bulla on the skin and whose biopsy indicates a suprabasal split?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation of bullous lesions and the histologic finding of a suprabasal blister, Pemphigus vulgaris is suspected.
  • This condition involves the production of antibodies, particularly against Desmoglein 3, and sometimes Desmoglein 1. These antibodies are typically of the IgG type. Desmoglein 3 is primarily found in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa.
  • As a result, patients exhibit flaccid bullae on the skin, and mucosal involvement, especially in the oral mucosa, is common.

 

 

  • Ulceration may also occur in other areas such as the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, and larynx. Cutaneous lesions are more frequently observed on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vegetans:

  • Description: Pemphigus vegetans is a variant of pemphigus vulgaris. It features vesicles and bullae that evolve into verrucous (wart-like) lesions, particularly in skin folds.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The primary presentation in the question doesn't describe verrucous or wart-like lesions.

 

Option C. Pemphigus foliaceus:

  • Description: Pemphigus foliaceus is another type of pemphigus but is characterized by more superficial skin blisters than pemphigus vulgaris, and it doesn't typically involve the mucous membranes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The biopsy of pemphigus foliaceus would show a split in the upper epidermis (subcorneal), not a suprabasal split.

 

Option D. Erythema multiforme:

  • Description: Erythema multiforme is an acute, immune-mediated skin condition. It is characterized by target-like lesions and is often triggered by infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus) or certain medications.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The presentation of erythema multiforme is quite distinct with its target-like lesions, and a biopsy would not reveal a suprabasal split.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is identified by the presence of flaccid bullae that rupture easily and a suprabasal split on biopsy, indicating an autoimmune process causing loss of epidermal cell adhesion.

 

 

Reference: 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 47.1-47.5, 50.1-50.10

Online resources:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3884912/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17619399/

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive muscle weakness, particularly affecting the eyes and throat, leading to difficulty with swallowing and drooping eyelids. Imaging studies reveal a mediastinal mass. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

The patient's symptoms of progressive muscle weakness, especially involving the eyes and throat, suggest myasthenia gravis, a condition commonly associated with thymoma. Thymomas are the most common type of anterior mediastinal mass and are frequently linked with autoimmune conditions like myasthenia gravis. In this case, the imaging reveals a mediastinal mass, which strongly indicates thymoma given the clinical context. Thymomas typically present as homogeneous, hypodense masses on imaging, though they lack specific features. Additionally, thymomas can be associated with other conditions such as pure red cell aplasia and Goode's syndrome (hypogammaglobulinemia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PTH adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are not associated with myasthenia gravis or mediastinal masses. They usually present with hypercalcemia-related symptoms and are not linked to muscle weakness or drooping eyelids.

 

Option C. Teratoma: Teratomas are also anterior mediastinal masses but are generally associated with more variable imaging features, including cystic or calcified components. They do not have a direct association with myasthenia gravis or the specific clinical symptoms presented.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: While lymphoma can present as a mediastinal mass, it usually presents with systemic symptoms such as fever, night sweats, and weight loss. It is not specifically associated with myasthenia gravis or the described muscle weakness and drooping eyelids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymoma is the most common anterior mediastinal mass associated with myasthenia gravis, presenting with symptoms like progressive muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and drooping eyelids.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with multiple patches of hair loss which was associated with itching and scaling. His 2-year-old sister also had similar complaints. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tinea capitis

 

Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that commonly affects children. It is characterized by multiple patches of hair loss, which are often associated with itching and scaling.

 

The history of a sibling with similar symptoms strongly suggests an infectious cause, which aligns with the diagnosis of tinea capitis. The condition is caused by dermatophyte fungi, and the transmission occurs via direct contact or shared objects, making it contagious, particularly among children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alopecia areata: This condition leads to sudden, patchy hair loss but is not associated with itching, scaling, or being contagious. It is an autoimmune disorder rather than an infection, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this context.

 

Option C. Seborrheic dermatitis: While this condition can cause scalp scaling, it typically does not lead to well-defined patches of hair loss or the contagious spread noted in this case.

 

Option D. Pediculosis capitis: Also known as head lice, this condition causes intense itching but does not result in patchy hair loss or scaling. The primary symptom is the presence of lice and nits (lice eggs) on the scalp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea capitis is a contagious fungal infection that presents with patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling, particularly in children, and can spread among family members.

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine US scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 126 mg/dL

 

Overt diabetes in a patient is diagnosed based on specific blood glucose levels. The criteria for diagnosing overt diabetes are:

 

  • Fasting blood sugar: ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • Random blood sugar: ≥ 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c: ≥ 6.5%

 

During pregnancy, maternal hyperglycemia, especially during the first trimester when organogenesis occurs, increases the risk of fetal congenital malformations, including cardiac malformations. This is particularly true for women with pre-gestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 106 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 106 mg/dL does not meet the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option C. 116 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 116 mg/dL is higher than normal but still below the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option D. 130 mg/dL: This is incorrect. Although higher than the threshold, the minimum level to suspect overt diabetes is 126 mg/dL, not 130 mg/dL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is diagnosed with a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dL, and maternal hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about propagated epidemics is incorrect? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) No secondary waves occur

 

  • Propagated epidemics are characterized by person-to-person transmission of disease, creating a distinctive epidemiological pattern. 
  • The statement that "no secondary waves occur" is incorrect because propagated epidemics typically may display secondary waves as the infection spreads through successive generations of cases.
  • The epidemic curve in propagated epidemics usually shows a series of progressively taller peaks followed by smaller ones, reflecting the pattern of disease transmission through multiple generations of hosts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exhibits successive peaks: This is accurate for propagated epidemics. The epidemic curve shows successive peaks representing multiple generations of cases as the disease spreads from person to person.

 

Option C. Involves person-to-person transmission: This is the defining feature of propagated epidemics. They only occur with diseases that can be transmitted directly from one person to another, such as HIV/STDs and polio.

 

Option D. Determined by serial interval: The serial interval (time gap between primary and secondary cases) is a key determinant of the pattern and timing of successive waves in propagated epidemics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propagated epidemics feature person-to-person transmission with a pattern of successive waves determined by the serial interval between cases, making the statement that secondary waves do not occur incorrect.

questions.text: Sleeping Sickness is transmitted by: [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (b) Tse-Tse Fly

 

Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis) is transmitted by the Tse-tse fly (Glossina). This vector-borne disease relationship is fundamental in tropical medicine. The Tse-tse fly serves as the biological vector that transmits the trypanosomes responsible for African sleeping sickness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sandfly: Sandflies (Phlebotamus) transmit diseases like Kala Azar, Oriental Sore, Changuinola virus, Sicilian virus, Oraya fever, Sandfly Fever, Chandipura virus, and Naples virus - not sleeping sickness.

 

Option C. Ticks: Ticks (both soft and hard varieties) transmit diseases such as Q Fever, Relapsing Fever, KFD, tick paralysis, tick encephalitis, babesiosis, Congo fever, tularemia, and tick hemorrhagic fever. They do not transmit sleeping sickness.

 

Option D. Louse: Lice are vectors for epidemic typhus, trench fever, relapsing fever, and pediculosis. They are not associated with sleeping sickness.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vector-disease relationships are specific and important in epidemiology. The Tse-tse fly (Glossina) is the definitive vector for African sleeping sickness, while the American form of sleeping sickness (Chagas disease) is transmitted by the Reduviid bug (Triatominae), also called the kissing bug or assassin bug.

questions.text: Common carotid artery pulse is taken at which level? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cricoid cartilage

 

Explanation:

 

The common carotid artery pulse is palpated at the level of the cricoid cartilage, which corresponds to the C6 vertebral level. The "magic of C6" is an important anatomical landmark.

 

At the C6 level, there is the cricopharyngeal junction, the cricoid cartilage, and the pulsation of the common carotid artery can be felt.

 

The common carotid artery lies just anterior to the carotid tubercle (also known as the Chassaignac tubercle), which is the anterior tubercle of the transverse process of the C6 vertebra. An artery is palpable when it lies close to a firm bony structure, and in this case, the common carotid artery is palpable due to its proximity to the carotid tubercle at the C6 level.

 

HNF Cadaveric section

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laryngeal prominence: The laryngeal prominence, also known as the Adam's apple, is located at a higher level than the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct landmark for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.

 

Option C. Suprasternal notch: The suprasternal notch is located inferior to the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct level for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.

 

Option D. Angle of mandible: The angle of the mandible is located superior and lateral to the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct landmark for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common carotid artery pulse is palpated at the level of the cricoid cartilage, which corresponds to the C6 vertebral level. The carotid tubercle of the C6 vertebra serves as a bony landmark for the pulsation of the common carotid artery.

questions.text: Identify the papillae of the tongue that serve a mechanical function but do not contribute to taste sensation. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Filiform

 

Filiform papillae are the most numerous papillae on the surface of the tongue. They are elongated, keratinized projections that cover the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Unlike other papillae, filiform papillae do not contain taste buds. Their primary function is to provide a rough surface that aids in the mechanical aspect of chewing by creating an abrasive texture that helps manipulate food.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Circumvallate: These papillae are located near the back of the tongue in a V-shaped arrangement just in front of the sulcus terminalis. They contain taste buds on their lateral surfaces and are responsible for the perception of bitter tastes.

 

Option C. Foliate: Foliate papillae are located on the lateral edges of the tongue. They contain taste buds that are responsible for the perception of sour tastes, although they are less prominent in humans compared to some other animals.

 

Option D. Fungiform: These mushroom-shaped papillae are scattered across the tongue's surface, particularly near the tip and sides. They contain taste buds and are responsible for the perception of sweet, salty, and umami tastes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Four types of papillae on the tongue:

  1. Filiform
  2. Fungiform
  3. Circumvallate
  4. Foliate

 

Taste buds are barrel-shaped structures located in the epithelium of the foliate and fungiform papillae, as well as on the lateral sides of the circumvallate papillae.

 

Taste buds are absent in the filiform papillae, which are the most numerous and smallest papillae on the surface of the tongue. They cover the entire dorsal surface of the tongue.

questions.text:
HDI is calculated by using ? [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Life expectancy at birth
  2. Mean years of schooling
  3. Gross national product
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) All three


The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite index used to measure the overall achievement of a country in three basic dimensions of human development:

 

  1. Health: Measured by life expectancy at birth, which reflects the average number of years a newborn is expected to live if current mortality rates continue to apply.
  2. Education: Measured by the mean years of schooling for adults aged 25 years or older and expected years of schooling for children entering school. This represent knowledge, enrolment ratio.
  3. Living Standards: Measured by Gross National Income (GNI) per capita, expressed in terms of purchasing power parity (PPP) in US dollars.

 

These components together provide a summary measure of average achievement in key dimensions of human development, allowing for comparisons across countries.

 

Educational Objective:
 

HDI is calculated using three components: life expectancy at birth, mean years of schooling, and Gross National Income per capita. These factors represent health, education, and living standards, respectively.

 

  • HDI range – 0 to +1
  • HDI (India) – 0.644 (Rank 134)
  • HDI (Switzerland) – 0.96 (Rank 1)

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presented with arthritis. She had a history of fever and sore throat 1 week ago. On examination, you hear a pansystolic murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. What is the finding you will see in the biopsy? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aschoff nodule

 

The clinical presentation suggests acute rheumatic fever (ARF), a sequela of untreated or poorly treated streptococcal pharyngitis. ARF can manifest with migratory arthritis, carditis (evidenced by the pansystolic murmur indicative of mitral regurgitation), and other systemic symptoms.

 

Aschoff nodules, or Aschoff bodies, are pathognomonic for acute rheumatic fever. These are areas of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by chronic inflammatory cells, including Anitschkow cells (macrophages with characteristic wavy nuclei). They are found in the heart tissue, especially in the myocardium, and are a hallmark of rheumatic carditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomyxoma: Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a condition characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity, typically originating from a mucinous tumor. It is not related to acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Caseating granuloma: Caseating granulomas are characteristic of tuberculosis and certain fungal infections. They consist of a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of activated macrophages and lymphocytes. This finding is not associated with rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Verrucous tumour: Verrucous tumors are typically warty growths and are not related to rheumatic fever. They can be associated with certain types of skin cancers or infectious warts but have no connection to the condition described in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of sore throat followed by symptoms such as arthritis and carditis, acute rheumatic fever should be considered. The presence of Aschoff nodules in biopsy is pathognomonic for this condition, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: Drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liposomal Amphotericin B plus 5-FC

 

Explanation:

 

The drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine (5-FC). This combination is used during the initial induction phase of treatment. 

 

Liposomal amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal that binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that lead to cell death. 

 

 

5-flucytosine is an antimetabolite that inhibits DNA and protein synthesis in fungal cells. The combination therapy provides synergistic effects against Cryptococcus, especially in the central nervous system infections like meningitis.

 

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis typically follows a three-phase approach:

 

  1. Induction phase - liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine
  2. Consolidation phase - fluconazole
  3. Maintenance phase- fluconazole

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is used in the maintenance & Consolidation phase of cryptococcal meningitis treatment, not as the primary drug of choice for acute infection. It's less effective than amphotericin B for the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option C. 5-Flucytosine: While 5-flucytosine is an important component of the treatment regimen for cryptococcal meningitis, it is not used as monotherapy. It has limited efficacy when used alone and is primarily used in combination with amphotericin B to enhance fungicidal activity.

 

Option D. Terbinafine: Terbinafine is an allylamine antifungal that inhibits squalene epoxidase, interfering with ergosterol synthesis. It is primarily used for dermatophyte infections (tinea infections of skin, hair, and nails).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is the combination of liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine for induction therapy, followed by fluconazole for maintenance & Consolidation therapy.

questions.text: The micronutrient deficient in a patient with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of skin and hair is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cu (Copper)

 

Copper deficiency can present with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of the skin and hair. Copper is a crucial cofactor for several enzymes, including tyrosinase, which is involved in the conversion of tyrosine to melanin, the pigment responsible for skin and hair color. When copper is deficient, melanin production decreases, leading to hypopigmentation. Additionally, copper plays a role in iron metabolism and immune function, which explains the anemia and neutropenia observed in copper deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zn (Zinc): Zinc deficiency is characterized by delayed wound healing, immune dysfunction, hypogonadism, and diarrhea. While zinc is important for various enzymatic functions, it does not specifically cause hypopigmentation or the combination of anemia and neutropenia seen with copper deficiency.

 

Option B. Se (Selenium): Selenium deficiency is associated with Keshan disease, which primarily affects the heart and can lead to cardiomyopathy. Selenium plays a role in antioxidant protection but does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Fe (Iron): Iron deficiency primarily causes microcytic anemia, fatigue, and pallor. It does not lead to neutropenia or hypopigmentation of the skin and hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copper deficiency is associated with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation due to its role in melanin synthesis and various other enzymatic processes.

choices.text: Both (a) and (b)

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Third trimester

 

Explanation:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a life-threatening medical disorder that primarily affects the liver during pregnancy. It most commonly manifests in the late second and third trimesters. AFLP is characterized by the accumulation of microvesicular fat within hepatocytes, leading to liver dysfunction. The diagnosis of AFLP is made using the Swansea criteria, which require six or more of the following clinical features for diagnosis:

 

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia, polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • Coagulopathy (raised PT, aPTT)
  • Increased bilirubin
  • Increased uric acid levels
  • Increased creatinine
  • Leukocytosis
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised serum ammonia levels
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • Microvascular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Risk Factors:

 

  • Maternal obesity
  • Male fetus
  • Primigravida
  • Multiple pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First trimester: AFLP is very rare in the first trimester, as it typically manifests later in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Second trimester: While AFLP can begin in the late second trimester, it is more commonly seen in the third trimester.

 

Option D. Both (a) and (b): AFLP does not commonly manifest in the first trimester and is primarily a condition of the late second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy most commonly manifests in the third trimester and is diagnosed using the Swansea criteria, requiring six or more specific clinical features.

 

Ref: Page no 2684, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Admit and give IV levofloxacin
Treat at home with oral Amox-clav
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought after a fall. He has a fever and confusion. On examination, he had a cough with rales. The patient was also tachypneic. How will you manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

 

Explanation:

 

This patient is likely suffering from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and presents with confusion, fever, cough with rales, and tachypnea. Given his age (65 years) and symptoms, a CURB-65 score calculation is necessary. The CURB-65 score assigns points based on confusion, urea level, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age ≥ 65. Here, the patient scores at least 3 points (confusion, tachypnea, age ≥ 65), indicating a need for hospital admission and potentially ICU care.

 

In managing CAP with a high CURB-65 score, empirical antibiotic therapy typically includes a combination of a beta-lactam (like ceftriaxone) and a macrolide or a respiratory fluoroquinolone (like levofloxacin). This combination is chosen to cover the most common pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and atypical bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin: Levofloxacin alone is a potent respiratory fluoroquinolone but may not provide sufficient broad-spectrum coverage

 

Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav: Given the patient's high CURB-65 score, home treatment is inappropriate. Oral antibiotics like Amox-clav are insufficient for severe CAP needing hospitalization.

 

Option C.  Admit and give IV ceftriaxone: While IV ceftriaxone is effective against many CAP pathogens, the addition of IV levofloxacin provides better coverage, especially for atypical organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with high CURB-65 scores and suspected severe community-acquired pneumonia, hospital admission and combination antibiotic therapy (such as IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin) are essential for effective management.

questions.text: The following scan is of a young woman on oral contraceptives. The most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hepatic adenoma

 

The image given is of hepatic adenoma which is the most frequent hepatic tumor in young women on oral contraceptive pills. Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors, predisposed in patients on OCPs and glycogen storage disorders with a predilection for hemorrhage. They are enhancing lesions on the arterial phase.

 

  • Liver tumors - IOC: Triple phase CT
  • Typical appearance of hemangioma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: More commonly associated with chronic liver disease and hepatitis B or C infections.

 

Option B. Metastatic infiltrates: Typically appear as multiple lesions with variable enhancement patterns depending on the primary cancer's nature.

 

Option D. Hemangioma: The most common benign liver tumor, characterized by its classic "light bulb" bright enhancement on T2-weighted MRI images, not typically associated with oral contraceptive use.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors often associated with the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs). They occur more frequently in young women and are known for their risk of hemorrhage.

questions.text: The given image is the logo for which of the following health programs? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) National Leprosy Eradication Program


The logo shown is for the National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP). The design of the logo holds significant meaning:

 

  • Sun: The sun in the center of the hand symbolizes hope and optimism, reflecting the positive outcomes of leprosy treatment.
  • Lotus Flower: This represents purity and beauty, indicating that there should be no stigma attached to those affected by leprosy.
  • Cured Thumb: The image of the healed thumb symbolizes that leprosy is a 100% curable disease. The thumb indicates that the affected person has been cured and is now a fully integrated member of society.
  • House-Shaped Hand: The hand shaped like a house emphasizes that the cured individual is an integral part of their family and community.

 

These elements collectively reinforce the message of hope, inclusion, and the need to remove stigma associated with leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrated Disease Surveillance Program (logo):

 

 

Option B.  National TB Elimination Program (logo):

 

 

Option D.  National Health Mission (logo):

 

 

Educational Objective:


The National Leprosy Eradication Program logo symbolizes hope, the curability of leprosy, and the inclusion of cured individuals into society, promoting a stigma-free approach towards the disease.

choices.text: It should not be given with pyrazinamide
It should be taken empty stomach
It is given as a loading dose

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis is being treated with voriconazole. He has been on the medication for two weeks and comes to the clinic for a follow-up. During the visit, he asks about the specific guidelines and considerations for taking voriconazole to ensure its effectiveness and safety. Which of the following statements is true about voriconazole? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is given as a loading dose
 

Voriconazole requires a loading dose to rapidly achieve therapeutic levels in the body. This is a crucial aspect of its administration, especially in acute settings where rapid antifungal activity is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with pyrazinamide: There is no significant interaction between voriconazole and pyrazinamide. Voriconazole does interact with many other medications due to its effect on cytochrome P450 enzymes, but pyrazinamide is not one of the primary concerns.

 

Option B. It should be taken empty stomach: Voriconazole can be taken either with or without food, but it is generally recommended to take it one hour before or one hour after a meal to ensure optimal absorption. While this is important, it is not the most critical consideration compared to therapeutic drug monitoring.

 

Option D. It requires therapeutic drug monitoring: While therapeutic drug monitoring can be important for voriconazole, especially in certain patient populations, it is not as universally mandated or emphasized as the initial loading dose regimen in standard treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the statement that voriconazole "is given as a loading dose" is the most universally applicable and critical aspect of its administration, especially for ensuring rapid therapeutic levels in treating fungal infections.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman whose last delivery was 5 years back presents with secondary amenorrhea of 2 years. She does not bleed on giving estrogen and progesterone. A laparoscopy shows the following. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Genital TB

 

The patient presents with secondary amenorrhea for two years and does not bleed when given estrogen and progesterone, indicating that the problem lies in the endometrium. The destruction of the endometrium can occur due to two main conditions: Asherman's syndrome and genital tuberculosis.

 

  • Asherman's syndrome involves intrauterine adhesions typically following a vigorous dilation and curettage (D&C).
  • Genital tuberculosis, however, causes chronic endometritis, leading to the destruction of the endometrium and the absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. The laparoscopy shows whitish caseating lesions on the surface of the uterus, which are characteristic of genital tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, commonly causing pelvic pain and infertility. It does not typically result in secondary amenorrhea or the absence of bleeding on hormone administration, and it does not produce the characteristic whitish lesions seen in the laparoscopy.

 

Option B. Fibroids: Uterine fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can cause menorrhagia, pelvic pressure, and pain but do not lead to secondary amenorrhea or absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. Fibroids also do not present with caseating lesions.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that rarely affects the genital tract. It does not cause endometrial destruction, secondary amenorrhea, or the absence of withdrawal bleeding when given hormones, nor does it produce the characteristic uterine lesions seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital tuberculosis can cause chronic endometritis and endometrial destruction, leading to secondary amenorrhea and absence of withdrawal bleeding on hormone administration, with characteristic whitish caseating lesions visible on laparoscopy.

questions.text: Which drug would be most effective in preventing withdrawal symptoms in a patient with a history of alcohol consumption who was admitted to the hospital after a road traffic accident? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Alcohol withdrawal can present with symptoms like anxiety, tremors, seizures, and delirium tremens, which can be life-threatening. Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, work by enhancing the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA, which has a calming effect on the nervous system, thereby reducing the risk of withdrawal symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This drug is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, not for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reduce cravings and prevent relapse in patients recovering from alcohol or opioid dependence. It is not used to manage acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic used for the management of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). It is not effective for treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the drugs of choice to prevent and manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a rash after a trip. You observe a vector on his skin. Considering common vector-borne diseases, what is the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image. ([INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Scrub typhus

 

Explanation:

 

The image provided shows a trombiculid mite, which is commonly involved in the transmission of Scrub Typhus.

 

  • Scrub Typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi and is primarily transmitted through bites of infected chiggers. The disease is prevalent in the Asia-Pacific region, so exposure in those areas following a rash and the sighting of a trombiculid mite on the skin strongly points to Scrub Typhus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Babesiosis: This is transmitted by Ixodes ticks (deer ticks), affecting red blood cells similar to malaria. It is not related to trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Anaplasmosis: Transmitted by deer ticks and the western black-legged tick, this disease targets white blood cells. It's also not transmitted by trombiculid mites.

 

Option D. Ehrlichiosis: This disease is transmitted by ticks like the lone star tick and affects white blood cells. It does not involve trombiculid mites.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Scrub Typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mites, specifically the chigger larvae. It is characterized by fever, rash, and a black eschar at the site of the mite bite.

 

DOC – Doxycycline (monotherapy)

 

If severe manifestations – Doxycycline + Azithromycin

questions.text: The commonest indication for liver transplantation in children is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliary atresia

 

Liver transplantation is a crucial life-saving procedure for children with liver failure. The most common indication for liver transplantation in children is biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is a condition characterized by a blockage in the bile ducts outside the liver, leading to progressive liver damage and cirrhosis.

 

For infants diagnosed with biliary atresia, a surgical procedure known as hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure) is performed to establish bile drainage. However, if the Kasai procedure is not successful in restoring bile flow, liver transplantation becomes necessary, often within the first year of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alagille syndrome: This syndrome, characterized by butterfly-shaped vertebrae and congenital heart disease (often pulmonary stenosis), results in infantile cholestasis due to a syndromic paucity of intralobular bile ducts. It is a less common indication for liver transplantation compared to biliary atresia.

 

Option C. Caroli disease: This is a rare congenital disorder characterized by dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. While it can lead to liver failure, it is not the most common indication for liver transplantation in children.

 

Option D. Hepatocellular carcinoma: This is a rare cause of liver transplantation in children. While liver tumors can necessitate transplantation, they are less common compared to biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children due to the progressive liver damage and cirrhosis caused by bile duct obstruction.

questions.text: Which Glycogen Storage Disease listed below does not typically result in Hypoglycemia? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II (Pompe's Disease)

 

Explanation:

 

Type II glycogen storage disease (Pompe's disease) is characterized by deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase (acid α-glucosidase). Unlike the other listed disorders, Pompe's disease affects glycogen breakdown in lysosomes rather than in the cytosol. The disease primarily manifests with accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes of multiple tissues - especially heart, muscle, and brain - causing cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, and neurological symptoms. Pompe's disease does not typically present with hypoglycemia as the primary metabolic derangement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I (Von Gierke's Disease): This is incorrect because Von Gierke's disease, caused by glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, is characterized by severe hypoglycemia. The enzyme defect prevents the liver from releasing glucose into the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Type III (Cori's Disease): This is incorrect because Cori's disease (debranching enzyme deficiency) does present with hypoglycemia, although it's typically less severe than in Type I. Mild hypoglycemia or early morning hypoglycemia is a characteristic.

 

Option D. Type VI (Hers' Disease): This is incorrect because Hers' disease (liver phosphorylase deficiency) does present with hypoglycemia, although it's generally mild. Mild hypoglycemia is a feature of this disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pompe's disease (Type II GSD) affects lysosomal glycogen breakdown and primarily presents with cardiac, muscular, and neurological symptoms rather than hypoglycemia, which is a prominent feature of GSDs affecting hepatic glucose release (Types I, III, and VI).

questions.text: Which amino acid in a protein is most commonly associated with O-glycosylation, facilitating the attachment of an oligosaccharide unit? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serine

 

Explanation:

 

Serine is most commonly associated with O-glycosylation, where oligosaccharide units are attached to the hydroxyl (-OH) side chain of serine residues. This is a post-translational modification that occurs during protein maturation. In collagen biosynthesis, hydroxylysyl residues undergo glycosylation when glucosyl and galactosyl transferases attach glucosyl or galactosyl residues to the hydroxyl groups. Similarly, serine residues, which also contain hydroxyl groups in their side chains, are primary sites for O-glycosylation in many proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamine: This amino acid contains an amide group in its side chain, not a hydroxyl group, making it unsuitable for O-glycosylation. Glutamine is involved in other forms of post-translational modifications but not O-glycosylation.

 

Option B. Cysteine: While cysteine has a sulfhydryl (-SH) group that can form disulfide bonds and participate in other modifications, it does not undergo O-glycosylation. Cysteine residues are important for protein stability through disulfide bridge formation.

 

Option D. Asparagine: Asparagine is associated with N-glycosylation, not O-glycosylation. In N-glycosylation, oligosaccharides are attached to the amide nitrogen of asparagine side chains, typically in the consensus sequence Asn-X-Ser/Thr (where X is any amino acid except proline).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serine residues, with their hydroxyl side chains, are the primary sites for O-glycosylation—a critical post-translational modification that attaches carbohydrate moieties to proteins, affecting their folding, stability, and biological function.

questions.text: A patient presents with xanthomas on the Achilles tendon. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Familial hypercholesterolemia

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. A hallmark of this condition is the presence of tendon xanthomas, which are cholesterol deposits typically found in tendons, most commonly in the Achilles tendon. This condition is caused by mutations affecting the LDL receptor or apolipoprotein B, which impair the clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. The Achilles tendon xanthomas are a distinctive feature that helps differentiate familial hypercholesterolemia from other lipid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tangier's disease: Tangier's disease is characterized by very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and the presence of orange-colored tonsils due to the accumulation of cholesterol esters. It does not cause tendon xanthomas, especially on the Achilles tendon, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Familial hyperchylomicronemia: This condition involves elevated triglycerides due to the accumulation of chylomicrons, often leading to eruptive xanthomas rather than tendon xanthomas. It is primarily associated with defects in lipoprotein lipase or apolipoprotein C-II and is not associated with the specific finding of Achilles tendon xanthomas.

 

Option D. Familial Dysbetalipoproteinemia: This condition, associated with a defect in apolipoprotein E, leads to increased levels of both cholesterol and triglycerides, often resulting in palmar xanthomas or tuberous xanthomas, not the specific Achilles tendon xanthomas seen in familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is associated with high LDL cholesterol levels and the presence of tendon xanthomas, particularly on the Achilles tendon

questions.text: A girl presents with short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield -shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The constellation of symptoms including short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankles, and increased carrying angle is suggestive of Turner syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome is caused by complete or partial X-chromosome monosomy. In phenotypic females, it causes hypogonadism. In females, it is the most common sex chromosome abnormality.

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries, infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Down syndrome: (Trisomy 21) is characterized by intellectual disability, facial dysmorphism, and increased risk of certain medical conditions such as congenital heart defects and leukemia.

 

Option C. Patau syndrome: (Trisomy 13): characterised by severe intellectual disability, cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, microcephaly, congenital heart defects, and often leads to early infant mortality.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: (Trisomy 18) characterised by severe intellectual disability, micrognathia (small jaw), clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, congenital heart defects, and also typically results in early infant mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest, peripheral lymphedema, and increased carrying angle, among other physical manifestations. It is caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome in phenotypic females.

questions.text: What is the best imaging study for diagnosis of cerebral infarct?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse weighted MRI

 

Explanation:

 

Diffusion-weighted MRI is the most sensitive investigation for diagnosis of cerebral ischemia.  It is particularly useful for identifying acute ischemic changes in the brain due to its ability to detect diffusion restriction of water molecules in the brain tissue.

 

 

Diffusion restriction: hyperintense on DWI and hypointense on ADC.

 

  • Diffusion restriction is seen with:
    1. Acute stroke
    2. Hypercellular tumors
    3. Abscess
    4. Epidermoid cyst
    5. Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FLAIR MRI: Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery (FLAIR) MRI is useful for identifying older infarcts and chronic changes but is less sensitive in the acute phase of a stroke.

 

Option B. Non-contrast CT: While commonly used for initial assessment due to its availability and speed, it is less sensitive in the early stages of a stroke, often not showing changes until several hours post-onset.

 

Option D. СECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): Typically used to assess for complications or other causes of symptoms but not as sensitive as DWI for early detection of cerebral infarcts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffusion-weighted MRI is the optimal choice for early detection of cerebral infarcts, making it an indispensable tool in acute stroke management. Its ability to show diffusion restriction provides critical information that can influence therapeutic decisions.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents at 8 weeks of pregnancy. During the examination, a specific clinical sign is observed. What is the name of the sign being elicited? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hegar sign

 

The image demonstrates Hegar's sign, which is elicited during bimanual examination in early pregnancy. Due to the softening of the lower uterine segment at the level of the isthmus, the examining fingers can be approximated between the cervix and the uterine body. This softening allows the examiner's hands to almost meet at the isthmus level during bimanual examination, which is characteristic of Hegar's sign.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Palmer sign: This is incorrect. Palmer sign refers to the detection of subtle uterine contractions felt during bimanual examination in early pregnancy, not the softening at isthmus.

 

Option C. Internal ballotment: This is incorrect. Internal ballotment is a second-trimester finding (after 16 weeks) where the fetus can be balloted between the examining fingers during vaginal examination.

 

Option D. External ballotment: This is incorrect. External ballotment is also a second-trimester finding elicited through abdominal examination, not applicable at 8 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hegar's sign as the softening of the lower uterine segment at the isthmus level during early pregnancy, allowing approximation of examining fingers during bimanual examination, and distinguishing it from other pregnancy signs.

questions.text: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The optimal time for determining the type of twin pregnancy through ultrasound is between 11+0 to 13+6 weeks, when the crown-rump length (CRL) is between 45 to 84 mm. This period allows for the most accurate dating and assessment of chorionicity, which is crucial for the management and outcome of twin pregnancies.

 

  • Chorionicity: The type of twin pregnancy (dichorionic or monochorionic) is determined by examining the thickness of the membrane at the site of insertion.
    • Lambda (λ) sign: Indicates a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
    • Inverted T sign: Indicates a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best time to determine the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.

 

 

Ref: Page no 2190, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below.(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colour Doppler

 

This technology uses standard ultrasound methods to produce an image of structures and also captures Doppler data to visualize moving blood cells. The color (usually red or blue) in the image represents the speed and direction of blood flow, relative to the ultrasound probe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. USG (Ultrasound): Standard ultrasound uses sound waves to create images of the inside of the body. It's primarily used to view organs and structures and can also detect abnormalities but does not inherently provide information about blood flow unless it includes Doppler capabilities.

 

Option C. X-ray: An X-ray uses radiation to produce images and cannot display blood flow.

 

Option D. CT (Computed Tomography): CT scans use X-rays from multiple angles to create detailed cross-sectional images of the body's internal structures.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In the image provided, the Color Doppler is displaying the blood flow within a specific blood vessel, likely a carotid artery (indicated by R Prox ICA, meaning the proximal right internal carotid artery). The Doppler waveform below the image shows the blood flow velocity during the cardiac cycle, indicating the health and patency of the vessel.

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+

 

ER+ is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients as it is seen with luminal A and B subtypes of the breast cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High Ki67+: High Ki67+ indicates a high proliferative index, which is associated with more aggressive tumors and a poorer prognosis.

 

Option C. BRCA1+: BRCA1 mutation is associated with an increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers, and these cancers tend to be more aggressive.

 

Option D. P53+: P53 mutations are associated with a variety of cancers and typically indicate a poorer prognosis due to the loss of normal p53 tumor suppressor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER-positive status in breast cancer is a good prognostic factor because it indicates a slower-growing tumor that is likely to respond well to hormone therapy.

 

Why ER⁺ is a Good Prognostic Factor:

 

  1. Slower tumor growth:
    • ER⁺ tumors tend to grow more slowly than ER⁻ tumors.
  2. Better treatment response:
    • ER⁺ cancers respond well to hormonal therapies such as:
    • Tamoxifen
    • Aromatase inhibitors
  3. Lower recurrence risk:
    • Hormone receptor–positive cancers have a lower risk of early recurrence.
  4. Overall survival:
    • Patients with ER⁺ tumors generally have better overall survival.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate has not passed urine since birth. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue breastfeeding and observe

 

  • A 1-day-old neonate not passing urine since birth is a normal finding in neonates. Continuing breastfeeding and observation is the next step in management.
  • Delay in passing urine or stool is a cause for concern and requires investigation.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Admit to NICU: This is not necessary as the absence of urination within the first 24 hours can be normal. Admission to NICU is reserved for cases where the neonate shows signs of distress or other serious conditions.

 

Option C. Start artificial feeding: This option is incorrect as breastfeeding should be continued unless there is a clear medical indication to switch to artificial feeding.

 

Option D. Start intravenous fluids: Starting IV fluids is not necessary unless the child shows signs of dehydration or is unable to take fluids orally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is normal for a neonate to not pass urine within the first 24 hours; continue breastfeeding and observe the baby.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby presents with bilateral cataract. A urine test is requested to suspect? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactosemia

 

Galactosemia is associated with congenital cataract, specifically presenting as "oil droplet central lens opacities" in infants. Galactosemia occurs due to deficiency of either galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (classical galactosemia) or galactokinase. In a 6-month-old with bilateral cataract, galactosemia should be suspected, and diagnosis is established by detecting reducing substances in urine when milk and milk products are consumed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Homocystinuria: This condition is associated with lens subluxation, typically in the inferior nasal direction, not congenital cataract. Diagnosis is established by the sodium nitroprusside test for homocystine in urine, but this wouldn't be the first suspicion in a 6-month-old with bilateral cataract.

 

Option C. Hyperlysinemia: This is an extremely rare condition caused by deficiency of the enzyme lysine alpha-ketoglutarate reductase. While occasionally associated with ectopia lentis (lens displacement), it's not characteristically linked to congenital cataract in infants.

 

Option D. Sulphite oxidase deficiency: This is a very rare autosomal recessive disorder of sulphur metabolism associated with ectopia lentis, not congenital cataract. It's a fatal disease with death usually occurring before 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In an infant presenting with bilateral cataract, galactosemia should be suspected and investigated with urine testing for reducing substances, as early dietary intervention can prevent progression and potentially reverse lens changes.

questions.text: A patient presented with hypertension, increased heart rate, and sweating. He sees red halos after hearing the radio. Which substance's abuse can cause this? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) LSD

 

The patient's symptoms include hypertension, increased heart rate, and reflex hallucinations (seeing red halos in response to auditory stimuli).

 

Reflex hallucinations occur when a stimulus in one sensory modality triggers a hallucination in another sensory modality, such as an auditory stimulus leading to a visual hallucination.

 

LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen known to cause such reflex hallucinations. Additionally, LSD can lead to sympathetic symptoms like hypertension and increased heart rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cocaine: Although cocaine can cause sympathetic symptoms such as hypertension and increased heart rate, it is less commonly associated with reflex hallucinations.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol abuse typically does not present with reflex hallucinations and the described symptoms.

 

Option C. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid that typically causes sedation and respiratory depression, not reflex hallucinations or sympathetic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

LSD, a hallucinogen, can cause reflex hallucinations, where a stimulus in one sensory modality (e.g., auditory) produces a hallucination in another modality (e.g., visual), along with sympathetic symptoms like hypertension and increased heart rate.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

 

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cutdown procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.
  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cutdown procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial Peroneal Nerve: This nerve originates from the common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve). It runs in the lateral compartment of the leg.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies sensation to the dorsum (top) of the foot and a small area over the lateral aspect of the lower leg.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution and potential weakness in eversion of the foot.

 

Option C. Femoral Nerve: Arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4).

 

  • Motor Functions: It supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh which are primarily responsible for hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory Distribution: Over the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg (via the saphenous nerve, its branch).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in hip flexion and knee extension along with sensory loss over its distribution.

 

Option D. Sural Nerve: This nerve is formed by branches from both the tibial and common peroneal nerves. It runs along the posterior and then lateral side of the calf.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies the posterolateral aspect of the leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A man presents with a history of hematemesis involving approximately 500 ml of blood. On examination, his spleen is palpable 5 cm below the left costal margin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Portal Hypertension

 

The patient presents with hematemesis (vomiting blood) and splenomegaly (enlarged spleen palpable 5 cm below the costal margin). These two findings strongly suggest portal hypertension as the most likely diagnosis. Portal hypertension is defined as an elevation of hepatic venous pressure gradient >5 mmHg and is directly responsible for variceal hemorrhage, a major complication that can present with hematemesis. The combination of splenomegaly and upper GI bleeding in the form of hematemesis is characteristic of portal hypertension.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Isolated splenic vein thrombosis: While this can cause localized portal hypertension with splenomegaly, it typically causes gastric rather than esophageal varices. The pattern of bleeding would be different, and it's much less common than generalized portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Drug-induced gastritis: This can cause hematemesis but doesn't explain the significant splenomegaly. Gastritis alone would not cause spleen enlargement of this magnitude (5 cm below costal margin).

 

Option D. Mallory-Weiss tear: This is a mucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction typically occurring after forceful vomiting. While it can cause hematemesis, it would not explain the splenomegaly, which is a key finding in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of significant hematemesis and splenomegaly strongly suggests portal hypertension with variceal bleeding, which is one of the major life-threatening complications of cirrhosis requiring prompt management.

choices.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old toddler with a weight of 11 kg was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. The child exhibited a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and upon examination, noticeable chest indrawing was detected. What is the next step of management? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Oral amoxicillin for five days

 

According to the latest revised guidelines by WHO, the management of childhood pneumonia has been updated based on new evidence. In the given scenario, a 2-year-old child presents with a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and chest indrawing, which fits the criteria for pneumonia but without general danger signs. According to the revised classification, the appropriate management for this case is oral amoxicillin for five days and home care advice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately: This is recommended for children showing general danger signs or very severe disease, not for pneumonia with chest indrawing without other danger signs.

 

Option C. Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours: This would be applicable for severe cases requiring inpatient care, not for managing a case of pneumonia without general danger signs at an outpatient department.

 

Option D. Start antipyretics urgently: While antipyretics may be used to manage fever, they do not address the underlying pneumonia and are not the primary management step in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The ligament that maintains anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Round ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The round ligament is responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus, particularly during pregnancy. It consists of smooth muscle extensions of the uterine corpus and is the homologue of the gubernaculum testis. These ligaments arise from the lateral aspect of the corpus just below and anterior to the origin of the fallopian tubes, extend laterally to the pelvic sidewall, and enter the retroperitoneal space. They pass lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels before entering the inguinal canal through the internal inguinal ring and terminate in the subcutaneous tissue of the labia majora. During pregnancy, the round ligaments stretch to accommodate the enlarging uterus, helping to maintain its anteverted position. It maintains the angle of anteversion of 120°

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cardinal ligament: Also known as the transverse cervical ligament or Mackenrodt ligaments, these provide significant support to the uterus and cervix by attaching the lateral aspect of the uterus and cervix to the pelvic walls. However, they do not maintain anteversion.

 

Option C. Uterosacral ligament: These ligaments insert broadly into the posterior pelvic walls and sacrum and form the lateral boundaries of the cul-de-sac (Pouch of Douglas). They play a role in supporting the uterus but do not contribute to maintaining anteversion.

 

Option D. Pubocervical ligament: This ligament forms part of the supportive structure for the uterus and vagina, attaching them to the pubic bone. It provides anterior support but does not maintain the anteversion of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The round ligament is primarily responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus, especially during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of these is a contraindication to the use of BiPAP ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unconscious patient

 

Explanation:

 

BiPAP, or Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure, is a non-invasive ventilation method that provides two levels of pressure: higher inspiratory positive airway pressure (IPAP) and lower expiratory positive airway pressure (EPAP). It is commonly used in various respiratory conditions but has contraindications. An unconscious patient may not be able to protect their airway, which increases the risk of aspiration. Such patients are typically not candidates for non-invasive ventilation like BiPAP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OSA (Obstructive Sleep Apnea): BiPAP can be used as a treatment for OSA to prevent airway collapse during sleep.

 

Option C. High CO2 (Hypercapnia): BiPAP is often used for hypercapnic respiratory failure because it can help blow off excess CO2.

 

Option D. Low Oxygen (Hypoxemia): While BiPAP can help improve oxygenation by increasing the alveolar ventilation, it may not be sufficient in cases of severe hypoxemia where invasive ventilation might be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BiPAP is contraindicated in unconscious patients due to the increased risk of aspiration and inability to protect their airway.

questions.text: In which container will you dispose of the needle with the syringe after vaccination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) White

 

Explanation:

 

The needle of the syringe, being a metallic and sharp component, should be disposed of in the white container after vaccination. The needle, being a sharp waste, goes into the white container, which is specifically designated for disposing of sharp and metallic waste.

 

After proper treatment methods like autoclaving, dry heat destruction, shredding, or mutilation, the contents of the white container are sent to iron foundries, sharp pits, or landfills for final disposal.

 

Plastic component of syringe – in Red container

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: CT scan given in the image is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural hematoma

 

Explanation

 

The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped hemorrhage, which is characteristic of a subdural hematoma (SDH). Subdural hematomas typically occur due to tearing of the bridging veins and are crescent-shaped because they can cross suture lines but are limited by the dural reflections.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Extradural (epidural) hematoma: Usually appears as a biconvex, lenticular shape and does not cross suture lines due to the tight attachment of the dura to the skull at the sutures.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Blood is found within the subarachnoid space, typically around the basal cisterns or within the sulci, and is not crescent-shaped.

 

Option D. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage: Appears as a hyperdense area within the brain parenchyma and does not have the crescent shape seen here.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

A crescent-shaped hemorrhage on a CT scan, especially if it crosses suture lines, is indicative of a subdural hematoma.

questions.text: Identify the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess and arteriotomy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 11

 

The blade shown in the image is number 11 blade used for skin incisions (E.g., Incision and Drainage) and Arteriotomy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

11 number blade is used In stab incisions needed when lancing an abscess or inserting a chest drain and in skin incisions and arteriotomy

questions.text: C-ANCA positivity is highly specific for?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wegener's granulomatosis

 

Explanation:

 

C-ANCA (cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) with specificity for proteinase-3 is highly specific for Wegener's granulomatosis, now called granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). More than 90% of patients with typical active granulomatosis with polyangiitis have detectable antibodies to proteinase-3. The specificity of antiproteinase-3 antibodies for Wegener's granulomatosis is very high (>95%), making it a valuable diagnostic marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa is ANCA-negative. It is a non-granulomatous medium vessel vasculitis without glomerulonephritis or pulmonary involvement, often featuring testicular involvement and microaneurysms visible on angiography.

 

Option C. Henoch-Schonlein purpura: HSP (now called IgA vasculitis) is characterized by IgA-mediated vasculitis with immune complex deposition rather than ANCA association. Diagnosis involves skin biopsy with direct immunofluorescence showing leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition in vessel walls.

 

Option D. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Now called eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), this condition is primarily associated with p-ANCA (perinuclear ANCA) with antimyeloperoxidase specificity rather than c-ANCA. Approximately 48% of patients with EGPA have circulating ANCA that is usually antimyeloperoxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-ANCA with anti-proteinase-3 specificity serves as a highly specific serological marker for granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's), providing an important diagnostic tool that helps differentiate it from other vasculitides that are either ANCA-negative or associated with different ANCA patterns.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with watery diarrhea and vomiting. Electron microscopy showed the following image. Identify the organism: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotavirus

 

The clinical presentation of watery diarrhea and vomiting in a 2-year-old child, combined with the electron microscopy image showing wheel-like structures, strongly indicates Rotavirus. Rotavirus is a leading cause of severe diarrhea in young children and is easily identified by its characteristic wheel-like appearance under electron microscopy. The virus is known for causing gastroenteritis in infants and young children, leading to dehydration if not managed properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenovirus: While adenoviruses can cause gastroenteritis, they do not have the characteristic wheel-like appearance seen in electron microscopy. Adenovirus typically presents with a different capsid morphology that lacks the wheel-like structure of Rotavirus.

 

Option C. Norwalk virus: Also known as Norovirus, this virus is a common cause of gastroenteritis but has a distinct cup-like morphology on electron microscopy, not the wheel-like appearance seen with Rotavirus.

 

Option D. Astrovirus: Astrovirus can cause diarrhea in young children, but it has a star-like appearance under electron microscopy, differing from the wheel-like appearance of Rotavirus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe diarrhea in young children and is characterized by its distinctive wheel-like appearance on electron microscopy.

questions.text: A patient with crushed limb after amputation developed crepitus. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gas gangrene

 

Explanation:

 

  1.  The patient had a crushed limb that required amputation.
  2. After the amputation, the patient developed crepitus, which refers to the presence of gas bubbles in the tissues.
  3. The development of crepitus after an injury or amputation suggests a gas-forming bacterial infection, specifically gas gangrene.
  4. Gas gangrene is caused by the bacteria Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens, which can contaminate wounds from soil or other environmental sources.
  5. Clostridium perfringens is a gas-forming bacteria that ferments sugars (such as glucose in the body) into acid and gas, leading to tissue necrosis and the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the gangrenous tissue.

 

The presence of crepitus, along with the history of a crushed limb and amputation, strongly suggests gas gangrene as the diagnosis.

 

Established agents:

 

  • C. perfringens
  • C. novyi
  • C. septicum

 

Probable agents: C. histolyticum, C. sporogenes, C. fallax, C. bifermentans, C. sordellii, C. aerofoetidum, and C. tertium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulitis: This is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth, but it does not typically involve the formation of gas bubbles.

 

Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis: This is a severe bacterial infection of the fascia (connective tissue) that can lead to tissue necrosis, but it is not specifically associated with the formation of gas bubbles.

 

Option C. Folliculitis: This is an infection of the hair follicles, which is unlikely to occur after an amputation and does not involve gas formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gas gangrene is a potentially life-threatening infection caused by gas-forming Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens. It is characterized by the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the necrotic and gangrenous tissues, typically occurring after traumatic injuries or surgical procedures that allow the contamination of wounds with soil or environmental sources.

questions.text: Where is Scarpa's Staphyloma typically observed? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myopia

 

Posterior staphyloma, also referred to as Scarpa's staphyloma, is typically observed in pathological myopia. It occurs due to ectasia (outward bulging) of the sclera at the posterior pole and appears as an excavation with blood vessels bending backward over its margins. This is a characteristic finding in high/pathological myopia, where the axial length increases abnormally, causing stretching and thinning of the ocular coats at the posterior pole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal Detachment: This is incorrect. While retinal detachment can occur as a complication of pathological myopia and may coexist with posterior staphyloma, the staphyloma itself is not a characteristic finding of primary retinal detachment. Retinal detachment is characterized by separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: This is incorrect. Glaucoma is characterized by optic disc cupping and not posterior staphyloma. The excavation in glaucoma involves the optic nerve head rather than the entire posterior pole as seen in staphyloma. Though myopic patients may have increased risk for glaucoma, posterior staphyloma is primarily associated with pathological myopia.

 

Option D. Iridocyclitis: This is incorrect. Iridocyclitis (anterior uveitis) primarily affects the iris and ciliary body in the anterior segment of the eye. Posterior staphyloma occurs in the posterior segment and is not a feature of inflammatory conditions of the anterior uvea. Iridocyclitis typically presents with pain, photophobia, and circumcorneal injection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior staphyloma is a defining feature of pathological myopia resulting from weakening and outward bulging of the posterior sclera due to excessive axial elongation, leading to characteristic fundus changes and increased risk for macular pathology.
